body: @kalyancv any update on this?

@kadaan another PR will deal with that. We probably need to make some changes to the `CommitStep` interface such as adding an argument (HiveMetaStoreClient) to the `execute()` method (otherwise everytime `execute()` is called it needs to create a new connection to Hive metastore). We are considering a few options.

Also, while I agree that for certain circumstances that HiveRegistration is critical, it is not a needed step for every gobblin use case.  I'm concerned about adding more and more logic to AbstractJobLauncher and JobContext that is not truly universal.

@zliu41 I think @kadaan brings up a good point. Perhaps it's possible to let Gobblin specify both a Task-Level Publisher and a Job-Level Publisher.

That should (1) avoid any changes to `JobContext`, and (2) let the hive-registration code be run in the driver.
Do you know what's going on with the Java 8 build on Travis? Let's just disable any tests that currently don't run on Travis using the `disabledOnTravis` tag.

@sahilTakiar 

Phantom node is the directory which does NOT exist on HDFS. For example, we have /data/databases in the ConfigStore, the phantom node may be /data/databases/foobar

The ConfigClient.getConfig(phantomNode) will return the resolved config of it's parent ( or ancestor )
So, just to make the logic in sync, the ConfigClient.getImports(phantomNode, true) , which return the imports recursively, need to return the imports recursively result of it's parent ( or ancestor )
Why is that only applicable for `getImportsRecursively`?

@sahilTakiar makes sense but the only problem is, the Job-level publisher will need to check whether it should publish data AND do hive registration, or only do Hive registration. Something like "if (data is already published in task level publisher) then (skip data publishing and only do Hive registration)". This is a little awkward. What if Hive registration is also done in the task level publisher?
Discussed offline, LGTM

You brought up the point that too many connections to the Hive Metastore may be dangerous. Its a valid concern, although maybe we can ask hadoop-dev and see what they think. If we can make all the connections at once, then we can just do the hive-registration in the task-level publisher.

If not, then we can have a `HiveRegPublisher` that only does hive-registration, not any publishing of data. 

For Task-Level publishing in Kafka the data is published at a task level, and then registered at the job level using `HiveRegPublisher`.

For Job-Level publishing, we can modify the `BaseDataPublisher` to use some composition technique with the `HiveRegPublisher`. A config option can control if `BaseDataPublisher` invokes the `HiveRegPublisher.publish()` method.

Even if we can make that many Hive connections, if two mappers publish to the same path, they'll be trying to add the same partition simultaneously which will likely be problematic.

Your alternative approach sounds good

@sahilTakiar updated. My feeling is that this new approach is more cumbersome than just making the change to `JobContext`. Let me know what you think.
@zliu41 Which approach are you talking about #701?
No, #701 is irrelevant. I was referring to the previous approach in this PR (I squashed that commit) which added a `doHiveRegistration` method in `JobContext` after the data is published.

Is `BaseDataPublisherDocumentingPathsPublished` necessary? Shouldn't the final output paths already be recorded in the `WorkUnitState`s? If they aren't we should just add the feature directly to `BaseDataPublisher`.

That should hopefully simply the PR a bit more. Even though it may be slightly more code, I still think its better since we are already introducing task level and job level publishers, which is a feature others may find useful.
I don't think that the publishoutputpaths are recorded in the workunitstates, but I think it would be a good idea to store them there. It would be trivial to add them in BaseDataPublisher.
@sahilTakiar  removed `BaseDataPublisherDocumentingPathsPublished` and added that into `BaseDataPublisher`.

@zliu41 addressed comments and modified approach slightly
- Instead of making a listener specific to `MRCompactor` I made a generic `CompactorListener`
- Added factory interfaces and implementations for creating `Compactor`s and `CompactorListener`s
- Re-factored `AzkabanCompactionJobLauncher` a bit to account for changes
- Main logic for this feature is in the class `HiveRegistrationCompactorListener`

We need a solution for retrying failed Hive registration, to avoid a dataset being published but not registered with Hive. Ideally this should leverage exactly-once, but since it likely won't be ready by Q1, a temp solution is needed, e.g., write failed dataset paths to an HDFS location which can be picked up by the next run to retry.

Yes, I will focus on the retry logic in the next PR as it may require some additional design work.

Hey @kadaan thanks for this PR, a lot of these changes will be very useful. Can you add some more documentation to some of the scripts you added here? Specifically the files under `./travis` and `./ gobblin-metastore/src/main/resources/db/migration/`

@eogren I believe you are also running the Job History Store. This PR has significant changes to the Store. Specifically, if you need to upgrade Gobblin the `./historystore-manager.sh` script will be needed (as outlined in the PR description).

Let us know if you have any issues with using flyway for schema migrations or any changes to the MySQL DDL / the `DatabaseJobHistoryStore` class.
Minor comments, otherwise LGTM.

@eogren @sahilTakiar The options I saw were using flyway, liquibase, or writing something ourselves.  Liquibase seems very flexible, but more complex.  Flyway is similar to solutions that we have written in house in the past.  I'm open to other solutions, but want to keep the following properties:
1. Developers can easily describe schema changes.
2. Code can determine if the DB is at the correct version
3. Users can easily upgrade their database
@sahilTakiar Added some documentation, renamed JdbcUrl, renamed TestMetastoreDatabase & PrivateTestMetadataDatabase.

@tuGithub I removed BaseDatasetCleaner as per @ibuenros 's feedback. Basically moved that logic to MultiCleanableDatasetFinder. 
For the config client we have a couple of options. 
1. We can pass the configClient from the job to the finder
2. We can keep some sort of singleton static instance
I do not like 1 as we need to pass around the client in all finders. We can do 2
Option 2 is fine with me

# New Configuration

`encrypt.key.fs.uri` is optional.  If it is not provided, then the code will perform as it did before.

# Example Configuration

To allow encrypted password to be used when gobblin in run under yarn, you need to make sure that the master password file is copied to the app_master and containers.  This is done by adding `/opt/apps/gobblin/current/master.pass` to `gobblin.yarn.app.master.files.local` and `gobblin.yarn.container.files.local`.  Additionally, `encrypt.key.fs.uri` needs to specify the local filesystem `"file:///"` and `encrypt.key.loc` need specify the master password file at the root of the current directory `master.pass`.

See the example below:

```
gobblin.yarn.app.master.files.local=${gobblin.yarn.conf.dir}"/log4j-yarn.properties,"${gobblin.yarn.conf.dir}"/application.conf,"${gobblin.yarn.conf.dir}"/reference.conf,{{ app_current_dir }}/master.pass"
gobblin.yarn.container.files.local=${gobblin.yarn.app.master.files.local}
...
encrypt.key.fs.uri="file:///"
encrypt.key.loc=master.pass
```

- The build seems to be failing because the tests are taking too many resources, which causes Travis to invoke a SIGKILL on the process, which is the cause of the `exit status 137`
  - See https://discuss.gradle.org/t/gradle-check-fails-but-tests-finish-with-success/10214
- The `disabledOnTravis` tag only works for some subprojects, currently working on fixing this

Adding `maxParallelForks = 1` didn't help.

Am going to wait until https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/743 is merged, after which the tests should no longer run on Travis and we should be good to merge https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/541
LGTM
LGTM.

@sahilTakiar I was thinking about maybe doing this a different way.  What if we recognized certain "tokens" in the app_master and container jvm arguments and replaced them when creating the java command.  The first token would be "$PORT_X" where X is a number > 0.  We would identify all such tokens and replace them with a random port.  All instances of the token which share the same X would have the same port.  This would be much more generic as I could then use YourKit, JMX, etc with the app_master and containers.

@kadaan In my experience, using random ports is not a good idea. Applications connecting to Gobblin with JMX will have a hard time figuring out the port.
I would suggest that user provides the port, and a port selection policy: either fail if the port is not available (default) or look for an available port in case of failure.
LGTM
